posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Advice on making a successful advice post on /o/:

If you are looking to get advice on a possible car purchase or car related problem, be sure to include:

What car or cars you are looking at or as detailed a description of the problem as possible. Include make, model, year, mileage, condition, any know faults, the asking price, and what your budget is!

If people have to ask you for every detail, you aren't going to get many replies!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1.)Get financing ahead of time/know your credit. You always want to have a financing option in hand before you go to a dealership. Nothing wrong with negotiating a better deal with them once you get there, but never go in empty handed. This way you can have idea of how much you can afford to spend, and what a car is going to cost you

2.)Do your research. Know what values KBB/NADA/Edmunds/TrueCar are listing for the cars you are interested in. Also know what other dealerships are listing similar cars for. Dealerships will prey on the uninformed, so make sure that you are

2b.)If you don't know enough about cars to inspect one yourself, arrange to get any used car inspected or bring someone who DOES know what to look for. It's surprisingly easy to polish up a turd and get it passed inexperienced eyes

3.)Never take the first offer, unless it's a place like CarMax that doesn't negotiate. Dealerships know the game, and they always get a certain number of people to bite on the first offer. make them work a little to get your business

4.)You can negotiate on more than the price. Oil changes, services plans, warranties, accessories are all fair game.

5.)In today's world, internet sales departments are your friend. You can send a blanket email to 3 or 4 dealerships and get them to compete for your business, let them haggle with each other before you ever haggle with them

6.)Get them to print you a Buyers Order for any car you are seriously, that is what you negotiate from. It will look like pic related, and itemize every line of the sale. Don't let them 4 square you or hand write shit on a piece of paper. Get a buyers order

7.)Never be afraid to walk away from a deal. If you have a bad feeling, sleep on it. There will always be other cars

posts.com:
DC Shoes was started by Damon Way and Ken Block after the two met during a community college class and launched a series of startups. The two friends started Eightball clothing, Blunt Magazine, Type A Snowboards, and Droors clothing over the subsequent years. Droors Clothing then became DC Shoes in 1993.

After he sold DC Shoes to Quiksilver in 2004 for $88 million in cash and stock, many industry insiders wondered what Block, the brand's co-founder, would do next. He had an impressive track record already, with years of marketing and sales experience.

Next came HOONIGAN
Ken Block, Co-Founder AKA Head Hoonigan in Charge, Brian Scotto, Co-Founder

Ken Block was a cool dude badass driver and had cool cars. He never seemed to act like some stuck up rich cunt.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
RIP

People shit on him for his racing record but he started racing when most professional racers would be thinking about retirement. First time he sat in a racecar was for a DC Shoes corporate event, and he impressed the instructors so much they suggested he should get into racing. He would sell his share of DC shoes off to start the rally team a year later. He was genuinely talented driver, but was identified too late to be competitive. He was racing against drivers who had a minimum of 10 years of racing experience on him. The fact he could come out of nowhere and hold his own is proof of that.

The whole Hoonigan thing and his race record make it easy to clown on him, but once you start looking deeper you'll understand he was the real deal, who complete reorganised his entire life around motorsport once he discovered it.

Just saw that a new Flow Battery company has just come out of stealth mode with a solution that works in cars and can store enough energy for 1000 miles of range.
Flow batteries have been used for grid storage for a while now since they're super energy dense, but until now nobody had miniaturized one enough to put it into a car because it requires pumping liquid around between storage tanks.
Its still not 1:1 with gasoline, but this is a 250kWh in a battery that weighs 250kg, and can be filled up in 5 minutes. By literally filling up the battery with fresh liquid.

Of course you have to drain the depleted liquid out and re-charge it before you put it back into the car, so its not exactly like gasoline, but it seems better than hydrogen fuel cells.
Seems like a perfect solution for electric endurance racing.

>>26211183
the easiest and one of the most worthwhile changes is to adjust brake pressure and bias to match your pedals. adjust both front and pressure while keeping bias constant, until you just barely start locking up at ~95% brake input. then adjust the bias to where you like the behavior of the car under braking. more front bias = more stable understeer during braking, more rear bias = more unstable oversteer during braking

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26212026
>It's EA you dumb fuck they have infinite money
Maybe you're the real retard. EA in the 2000's had infinite money in comparison to the 90's, where they were still growing and making a name for themselves, yet you don't see regional content differences in BlackBox's titles Most Wanted. Region-exclusive content is a fad practice of the 90's. From racing games to adventure and fighting games and everything inbetween, region-locking was common because markets were very self-enclosed back then, the internet was extremely young and what an European market found alluring wasn't what an Australian market would find that way, there was not enough power of an unified group of people to make a single international market for a game like nowadays, so you either attracted individual markets for unified revenue or you just marketed your game to the local market without risking a failed export attempt.
The same idea was perfectly true with cars, movies, music, etc.

posts.com: can i do serious drifting with just paddle shifters and e brake? no clutch

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26216186
no
a clutch kick is an essential technique, without a way to do that you cannot control your rotation or slide radius. once oversteer starts you will just have to ride it into whatever tree you are aimed at.
you can drift you just cannot hit crazy angles or do reverse entry, 360 spin, etc. also if the paddle shifters are attached to the wheel hub it is very easy to get crossed up and mis-shift.
for me the ability to use an h-shifter to drop down multiple gears and be able to accurately shift up in the middle of a drift is key to good drifting. you can do it with paddles it is just much much harder, and you really and truly need a clutch pedal or at least a way to open and drop the clutch to actually be able to control the car mid-drift at all.

if i may recommend set your steering lock to 540, this prevents you from getting the steering crossed up and will alleviate some of the issues with the paddles. you should be able to go full lock to lock without removing both hands from the wheel. at each end of lock your wrists should basically be touching. then in car setup adjust the front toe to something like -0.30, -0.40, or even less, this is ideal retard drift mode and will let you do very cool drifts without a lot of effort

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26216249
you cant change angle with the brake and ebrake?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26216251
no because they also slow you down with kills the momentum and stops the drift.
the clutch allows you to cut all torque to the wheels and immediately drop it back on again. the handbrake allows you the additional step of jamming those wheels into a full stop, with causes them to slide like casters, and then you use the normal brakes of the car to -- once the sideways drift has started -- rotate the body about the front wheels which should be in a state of understeer that pulls the car into an arc. you then drop the spinning engine back onto the rear wheels via the clutch once the vehicle is pointed in the direction you want to go, which, provided the alignment is good, should thrust you forward and around the corner like a rocket achieving orbit.
without a way to cut the engines momentum off the wheels you cannot rotate the car sideways whilst still moving in a straight line.

the handbrake is primarily used to aid rotation in small spaces and sharp corners where flicking the car outwards with inertia isn't possible, and pretty much requires you have a clutch to use it, if you rip the handbrake in a real life car and don't press the clutch pedal, the engine stalls and you just crash. in AC you cannot stall but you will still just spin out and crash, you need to use the clutch to rev the tits off the engine so that it's actually making power by the time you drop the clutch.

posts.com:
Excuse my ignorance.
I assume sport-oriented engines are more sensitive to gas pedal inputs (less time from when you push the pedal to when the revs increase)
Why is that?
While powerful engines obviously reach high rpms faster, they also drop rpms faster
What is responsible for the latter? Doesn't sound too hard to achieve mechanically, why not make normal cars more responsive?

I noticed that my fwd 90 hp station wagon shitbox has the smoothest shifts when upshifting at low rpms , or grannyshifting if you will. If I reach the optimal higher rpms for acceleration and then upshift, the shift is more jerky, I feel more weight moving to the front of the car every time I clutch in. This must fundamentally happen with powerful engines too? Or does the sporty suspensions mitigate it? I guess a sportier weight distribution like rwd helps too, right?

And also, the rpms don't drop quickly. If I try to upshift faster, the clutch first needs to lower them before I can accelerate since they haven't dropped enough, which ofc is not ideal. I guess this is normal? Economy small engines want to be driven lightly and are engineered so people who change gear more slowly can operate them optimally?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Less displacement = less engine brake
Commuters cars have softer suspensions, which means more pronounced weight transfer. Just drop the clutch once the gear is in when upshifting, that's the thing holding you back probably. Anyways eco cars are not made for spirited driving, so don't expect much.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26220902
Sporty cars will usually have lighter engine components + flywheel and shorter gear ratios.
This is why they drop revs faster, there's less momentum.
People who want to drive "normal" cars want smoothness and feel distant from the mechanical feel of a "raw" car, so these cars have flywheels with more weight, a fuel mapping that focuses on smoothness and economy, more insulation and in modern "drive by wire" cars, a throttle mapping that isn't linear.

The jerkiness during shifting happens due to the crankshaft's RPM and Gearbox's input shaft RPM not matching up.
You'll have to figure out at what RPM you can upshift to the next gear for a smooth transition. It depends on the car and gearbox ratios. Letting the clutch off slowly allows you to increase the "margin of error", since you give the two shafts time to sync up before the clutch fully synchronizes their speed.
For example, in my NA Miata, all the upshifts from 2nd to 3rd, 3rd to 4th and 4th to 5th are super smooth when I do them as fast as I can, due to how small the difference in gearing ratio is between those.
From 1st to 2nd however, I have to do it much more slowly and wait for the revs to drop, else the car jerks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Small engines can only make power (naturally aspirated) by revving high, high revving engines pick up revs FAST when there's no load, but they make fuck all torque when there is load.
It makes them pretty shit to learn the clutch on because it's easy to moon the revs, but then if you release the clutch to quickly there's no torque to pull it through.

A larger, lower revving motor will take longer to climb the revs and it will have more torque. A diesel in a commercial truck for example can drive away at idle and the revs only climb as much as the throttle.

Basically on a commercial diesel half throttle might only bring the engine up to half RPM even without any load.
But a quarter throttle on a small sports motor might allow the engine to rev all the way to redline.
But if you put a load on them the diesel will still get to half RPM and hold it, while the small sports motor might stall out at 1/4 throttle.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26220902
>I assume sport-oriented engines are more sensitive to gas pedal inputs (less time from when you push the pedal to when the revs increase)
>Why is that?

Couple of things could be responsible for that.
>Electronic throttle
Econoboxes with drive-by-wire systems are tuned so that throttle response ramps rather than reacts instantaneously. That's done to avoid retards shocking drivetrain components when they mash the throttle rather than squeeze it. Downside is that there's a noticeable lag between stabbing the gas pedal and the engine actually revving.
>Flywheel weight
Since we're talking manuals, the weight of the flywheel affects how much "pep" an engine feels like it has. A heavy flywheel makes an engine feel sluggish and lazy, but conserves energy better so that the clutch take up is *easier* and doesn't require so much throttle input. A light flywheel will make an engine feel more rev-happy but it gets irritating to drive in traffic. Remember, heavier flywheel conserves more energy and an engine will drop revs far quicker with a lighter flywheel.

>While powerful engines obviously reach high rpms faster, they also drop rpms faster
Lighter flywheel and better balanced rotating assembly.
>why not make normal cars more responsive?
Making a rotating assembly lighter would improve response at the cost of increasing harshness and vibration at idle and low RPM.

>If I try to upshift faster, the clutch first needs to lower them before I can accelerate since they haven't dropped enough, which ofc is not ideal. I guess this is normal?
I mean, most people would shift slowly enough to the point that engine revs would drop sufficiently upon the release of the clutch to make the engine and transmission speed matched close enough to avoid a shock. Depends on the car though I guess. Use the throttle to keep the revs up a little while you've got the clutch in to make a fast shift a bit smoother?

Classic cars are often prized by collectors and enthusiasts for their aesthetic appeal, workmanship, and historical significance. The GM EV1 was a battery electric vehicle produced and leased by General Motors from 1996 to 1999. It was the first modern electric car produced by a major automaker and the first mass-produced and mass-marketed electric vehicle in the United States. The EV1 was available only in California and Arizona to comply with the Zero Emission Vehicle mandate of the state of California. The EV1 was discontinued in 1999 and all vehicles were recalled and taken back by GM in 2003, causing controversy and raising questions about the role of the automobile industry and the future of electric cars.

posts.sub: How do I make my car more urban?
posts.com:
There are several ways you could make your car more suitable for urban driving:

Install a backup camera or rear-view camera to make it easier to park and navigate tight spaces.

Consider adding sensors or other safety features to help you avoid collisions in crowded city streets.

If you frequently drive in areas with poor air quality, you might want to consider adding a particle filter to your car's air intake system.

Consider replacing your car's traditional gasoline engine with an electric or hybrid powertrain, which can be more efficient and emit fewer pollutants in urban areas.

Look into aftermarket options like parking assist systems, which can make it easier to parallel park or fit into tight spots.

If you frequently drive in crowded cities, you might also want to consider a smaller, more agile vehicle that is better suited to navigating busy streets and tight corners.

There are several ways to reduce the amount of time you spend on your phone and to be less reliant on it:

Set limits on your phone usage: Many smartphones have built-in tools that allow you to track your phone usage and set limits on certain apps or activities. You can use these tools to help you manage your time more effectively and reduce the amount of time you spend on your phone.

Take breaks from your phone: Try to schedule regular breaks from your phone throughout the day. During these breaks, put your phone away and engage in other activities, such as reading a book, going for a walk, or spending time with friends and family.

Find alternative ways to stay connected: Instead of relying on your phone to stay connected with others, try using other forms of communication, such as phone calls, text messages, or in-person conversations.

Turn off notifications: Many people feel the need to constantly check their phones because they are alerted to new notifications. Consider turning off non-essential notifications or setting your phone to "do not disturb" mode when you want to focus on other tasks.

Keep your phone out of reach: If you find it difficult to resist the urge to check your phone, try keeping it out of reach when you are not using it. This can help you to avoid the temptation to pick it up and check it constantly.

Riding between cars, also known as lane splitting or white lining, is generally considered to be a dangerous and risky maneuver, and it is not legal in many places. It involves riding a motorcycle on the lines that divide lanes of traffic, often at high speeds and in close proximity to other vehicles. This can be very dangerous, as it leaves the rider vulnerable to collisions with other vehicles, as well as the risk of being hit from behind by a following car. In addition, other drivers may not expect a motorcycle to be riding between lanes, which can lead to unexpected and dangerous situations. It is generally safer to ride in a designated lane and avoid lane splitting.

>why they are forcing us into an EV
ICE cars are highly problematic

Due to the fact that any knucklehead with some simple metallic tools and some non-volatile mechanical component parts can keep an ICE vehicle on the road indefinitely, we have a big problem on our hands. Conspiracy theorists and anti-vaxxers and dangerous anti-government inclined citizens can keep their old legacy cars forever without upgrading

EVs are the ideal solution
EVs have planned obsolescence built in. The expensive complicated non user-maintainable battery packs will be severely degraded in 5 short years, and basically useless after 10 years. Just like an old laptop or smartphone. By controlling maintenance and provision of new battery packs, or ensuring that battery packs are not replacable, we have turned the car into the ideal consumerist item.

This is a good thing
Now, people cannot keep their dangerous old cars indefinitely, but are forced to buy newer safer cars every few years. This is safer for our children and better for the planet as they will be replaced with more efficient cars and newer designs. It will also generate more money for manufacturers allowing them to innovate more quickly
The government can also introduce new safety features by mandating them in all new cars, and in only a few short years every car on the road will be compliant due to their short lifespan. Previously there were dangerous legacy cars which were grandfathered in indefinitely and non-compliant dangerous cars were allowed to roam freely. Future generations will look back in amazement at the fact we allowed this

All we have to do is bring in a ban for ICE cars soon into the adoption of EVs, or since this will be an unpopular move, we simply have several amnesties or "cash for clunkers" style schemes to ensure all dangerously reliable ICE cars are removed from circulation. This should get 99% of them except for a few paranoid holdouts who we can monitor through normal channels.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26214858
That's cool. My point still stands though. That is a lot of baseload capacity, and not much peak capacity.
Which is why they are setting up this potential system to prevent brownouts at peak demand.

All it really means in the short term is EV fast charger installers will add battery systems to supply the power instead of drawing directly on the grid baseload, and more people will install home storage systems. Both of which allow shifting base load over production at times of low demand (and low prices) so they don't have to draw on the grid when demand (and prices) are high.

>EU for example reducing their power production in favour of ''green'' energy
Except that they're not reducing power production in favor of green energy, they're increasing their power production building clean energy sources like nuclear power plants, solar, wind, and hydro electric.
Nobody wants to subsidize expensive dirty energy sources that give power to Europe's enemies anymore.

Also that 30% back on the napkin estimate for the US is using a very high end estimate for transmission losses and charging overhead, isn't taking into account reductions in electricity use by the fossil fuel industry, and is using current efficiency for EVs when EVs are getting lighter and more efficient.

> why they're forcing us to adopt EV's so much.
Nobody is "forcing" anyone to adopt EVs, just like no one was "forced" to adopt LCD TVs. The technology was just better, allowing for lower prices and better outcomes in the vast majority of use cases so it took over.
Same thing is happening with EVs. As recently as 15 years ago the best EV in the world barely had the equivalent energy of 1.5 gallons of gas because a kWh of batteries cost $1000 USD and in the battery pack that weighed about 10kg.
Today that kWh of batteries costs about $100 and weighs about 6kg, and its hard for old fashioned pure ICE cars to compete.

When batteries drop in price to $50 and get to around 2kg for a kWh its going to be impossible for fossil fuel cars to compete, especially with the faster charging already rolling out.
That next-gen solid state Porsche 911 everybody keeps talking about could have a 200kWh battery that weighs just 400kg, and adds 400 miles of range in 5 minutes.

If it's freedom to travel, then airplanes and trains go places for cheaper and with less stress on the environment. Travelling with a car necessitates bringing a car with you, repairing it, fuelling it, etc. That form of travel can be more restrictive than just taking a train somewhere.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Bait. Common sense will tell you that if the snow is near or exceeding the ground clearance of your car, then you'll get stuck. Other than that you should be fine. I've been driving my Z for 3 winters now (NH) and I've been fine. The only time it's sketchy is when there is too much accumulation on the roads, or when I stop on hills. Other than that I just go slow and avoid other retards. I do have to say, it was pretty fucking terrifying the first few times I drove through blizzards. In my Crosstrek all I had to do was push the gas pedal and if I lost traction I would instantly get it back as long as I didn't slam on the brakes. In the Z, I have to really pay attention. My shifts have to be smooth, I have to be in the right gear, and if I lose traction it's 100% on me to get it back. Letting off the gas or hitting the brakes is a guaranteed accident, knowledge of drifting is basically required. Overall it's fun but it can be a lot more stressful than your typical NPC car especially if your new to rwd/snow.

>>26217524
At 100k you start having issues with most forced induction engines. It's not a guarantee you will have problems but I wanted OP to be aware.

Turbos start getting to the end of their life around 100k for example. You could get 150k out of a turbo or the waste gate flap could become loose at 102k and suddenly you need a $2000 replacement turbo plus $600 labor. Diverter valves go around this milage too although that's usually a $200 fix at a shop. Pipes could age and cause boost leaks, etc.

I think the Lexus is a naturally aspirated V6 right? So you wouldn't have these issues

Determination really is the key.

I've bought boards off fleabay in the off season (I've paid more for shipping than the board). I scored a basically brand new Jeenyus (pre Burton buyout) for my girlfriend that looked like some chick got her dad to buy her gear, tried the bunny slope once and said fuck it. So it's definitely worth it to shop around and wait for a deal.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26200766
>the jeep compass trailhawk pro -
For the love of God do NOT buy one. I owned one for two years after having a cheap ass jeep patriot i got at 17 that lasted 11 years. The patriot was ok and it could offroad just enough. BUT the compass "trailhawk" was the biggest peice of shit. The brand new engine burned a quart of oil every 1000 miles, which I only found out because one day driving down the highway my engine shuts off at 60 mph after a "low oil pressure" warning flashed up for 5 seconds. This happened the first time aound 10k miles. And several times after that despite me pouring a fresh quart in once a month. I was then told that the oil consumption rate was normal by the dealership. Aside from that I had shit break on it constantly. Half the parts are from a fiat 500 and it's 4wd is actually just AWD. The final nail in the coffin was when my battery died, but it wasn't actually my battery. It was a very small sub battery that sat on top of my normal battery that INDEPENDENTLY powered the starter motor. So I had a totally fine battery, but because some AA Duracell shit was dead the fucking car wouldn't start. I sold it back to the dealership and bought a 4runner instead and it runs like a dream.

-engine oil and filter change
-replace brake fluid

>fire truck up for an oil change
>hoping to get to drive it this winter as ive been neglecting it for a few years now
>fire it up
>idles at 2k
>shut it off
>unplug idle air motor
>500rpm idle to limp it around
>drive it down the street
>it won't shift or shifts nonsensically
>read about symptoms
>talk to frens
>theyre saying that either it's a vaccum leak or tps
>read about voltage range for tps
>it's like 0.5 to 5v
>check it with throttle shut
>3v
>order a new tps
>install it
>truck run happy and shifts now
happy truck

posts.com:
The timing chain on my suzuki got loose, skipped a few teeth and ran super rough for a couple days and then I spun a bearing on one of my con rods :(

I tried to get the engine out to work on it, but I needed to undo the entire front end and drop the engine out from underneath the car. I don't have a lift to do that so I did everything I side the engine bay which sucked.

Changed the whole timing chain assembly, and swapped all the con rod bearings. The rod journal on the crankshaft of the spun bearing is gouged to shit. I polished as best I could with sandpaper, replaced the bearing and put everything back together. Finished the job yesterday. Surprisingly the car runs super smooth now. Better than before lol

I don't trust the car or my bogan fix so I think I will sell it and buy a Toyota

posts.com:
I'll make my case in defense of SLAV/Euro car and tuning culture.
With my decent understanding of American car culture and preferences to engines and mods, I can tell you a few reasons European car culture is so varied and different.
Under most countries' laws here, any car deal needs to be certified and registered to the individual, no pink slips or anything of the like.
Under EU law we are taxed on displacement and horsepower(KW) of the engine, which makes 1000cc-2500cc engines more than twice as cheap on YEARLY taxes as say a 4L V8.
Technical inspection is required once a year and power and emissions are tested to see if you're up to something funny maybe.
Tuning and mod culture. Varies a lot from country to country, with the more famous/notorious ones being UK and Slavic car scenes, with everything from riced out hatchbacks to tastefully tuned BMWs, Audis and Mercs.
The reasons why the Audi 1.9TDI and the 1.8t 20v engines are so popular is because they've been around in many different VAG cars and tunes over the years from 130hp to 240hp from the factory and can be pushed to 350hp on mostly OEM upgrades, which are cheap and abundant. Nothing beats swapping RS3 parts in your Polo.
Engine swaps are uncommon as you need to basically register the engine as a second car, we work with what we have and whatever has the most bang for the buck and can still remain road legal.
Our roads are also much different to the US, 250hp might not be much on the US highways, but it's plenty on twisting European B roads.

basically it all comes down to the safety laws regarding the front end of the car. there has to be a lot of space between the engine and the hood so that if you hit a pedestrian the hood has room to bend down rather than the person basically just smashing into the engine. so because of this law hoods had to be higher which means the driver's seat has to be higher to see over the hood which means the roof has to be higher to give enough head room. and because the whole car is taller it also has to be a little wider. proportionally the end result is that the belt line goes up, the belt line is basically the top of the fenders and the bottom of the windows. the amount of car below that line is much taller than older cars used to be in past decades. so the proportions are fucked, and the only thing you can do to somewhat help the proportions are just put bigger wheels. they cut up into the fender and lower the car so it doesn't look like a covered wagon.

what i just described is exactly why cars look like toys.

there are other things as well. for example almost every car has an arch shaped roof. it looks horrible, it's why cars look like bars of soap but the reason is because it's very strong so if you flip the car the roof won't collapse and decapitate you the way it would on an old car with a flatter roof. And on to of that the C pillars are much wider for the same reason which also doesn't look good. Many cars for example Camrys have black plastic on the C pillar to make it look like it's part of the window. once you notice its embarrassing and really really cheapens the car. makes it look like a toy. there are other things. but yea those are the main ones i guess.

Wrong. There are breathable and rainproof motorcycle clothes available, but these clothes are more often made from textile materials than leather. To reduce fogging issues to visor of the helmet there are Pinlock visor's available that can be installed to helmet or mounted to stock visor. Also there are breath deflectors available that can be installed into helmet and these breath deflectors reduce fogging by preventing the rider from breathing out directly to visor.

Dont drive much above speedlimit and should be quite safe even on rainy days. Tires should be good quality and correct type for the motorcycle because lots of tires that can be mounted to the rims but they dont offer proper traction with a wrong type motorcycle. Tires should be less than 6 years old and not bald.

>>26213537
From what I have seen, the high prices are not only the result of inflation and increased safety mandates but also the tendency of car manufacturers to make more expensive cars.

When I was young in the 80's and 90's, it was common for manufacturers to offer a very cheap car as the baseline that was manufactured in large numbers but had very little profit per unit made. Over the last 20 years, this attitude has gradually changed. What happens now is that car manufacturers are making cars that have more standard equipment and features that also feature better parts quality, especially on the interior. They can sell these at a higher profit.

So basically everyone is chasing the market that is slightly more wealthy than they were aiming for a few decades ago. The cheapest new cars on the market are better equipped but more expensive. This pushes some new car buyers from the new cheap car market into the slightly used market and higher demand leads to higher prices for all used cars.

posts.com:
>>26207959
Having driven both a Mercedes like this, and a Tesla I have to say that I like Tesla's implementation better.

Tesla does stuff that makes the screen not annoying like knowing when sunset is every day and automatically switching to night mode which lowers the brightness, goes to dark mode styling, and minimizes the blue on the screen so you're not bleaching your eyes.
Mercedes meanwhile has settings that let you change every little thing about the dashboard displays and the interior accent lighting, but it seems to just keep the same color settings all the time.

If Tesla is Gnome, Mercedes seems to be going the KDE approach. The Merc feels more gimmicky, like they're just throwing in all the bells and whistles they can without thinking about the whole. The Tesla interface by contrast feels better thought out even if its not as configurable.
Its honestly not what I was expecting at all. I had the idea of Merc as a more refined and aristocratic brand.

Not to say Tesla's implementation is perfect, honestly it was better a year or two ago and has gotten worse because they seem to have employed UI designers who weirdly aren't thinking about the fact its a car and the driver is going to need to control things without taking their eyes off the road. Things that used to work as imprecise gestures now require precise taps.
Car makers should really take a look at Valve's Steam Input and take a page from that. Give the driver some additional controls they can configure as they see fit or use as modifiers.

I'm guessing that within 10 years most cars will have a full screen dash, assuming it's not an entirely autonymous car, but the screen will not be composed of multiple square screens that are then masked to appear as one single unit. the screens will stretch for the entire span without blocks, it will not be a composition of large screens but cropped on a pixel level, kind of if you have seen those modular led advertisement boards where they just swap the single pixel unit if it breaks. not saying car makers will make it repairable like this but the point is the screen will be spread like canvas and doesn't need to have some basic ass masking techniques to hide the fact that it's just a fancy collection of ipads with an OS they will not support for long enough

I would also guess that one of the manufacturers comes up with a way to alter the structure of the surface of the screen, like for when there's a need for a dial it will just push up a point in the screen to simulate a knob. we've seen it on a concept stage so it won't take long to get into cars and other vehicles. they just need to make it last for a long time without signs of wear, kind of when they started making those folding smartphones

posts.name: Lm7bird
posts.com:
Just got back from test driving the sway bars I put in. 1-2am nobody was on the road so I was able to Hoon that poor car for everything it's got. And man does it have more to give. First I'm gonna say one of the biggest improvements aside from the obvious was launch stability. The rear end stayed flat and it felt like both tires had even grip even under a hard launch which is impressive considering the whole open diff thing and the rear sway bar probably does something to help with axle wrap. Now for the obvious, around the corners it stayed perfectly flat with almost no understeer and the throttle input to induce oversteer was far more predictable and importantly consistent allowing me to kick out the rear end counter steer and get the car going the right way. The abundance of right hand turns made this easy to test and get a hang of. My only complaint is the car seems to rock now which kinda sucks going from my glorified boat suspension but the performance gain and the tire wear aspect of not leaning onto the outside shoulders of the tires should make the bullshit all completely worth it.
>Mfw I hit this right turn at 40 with the most graceful power slide before flooring it away and hitting redline

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
They're unapologetic shitboxes and do their job with varying degrees of success.
Sure you can't compare a Zhiguli to an E30 BMW, but when compared to something closer to their price point like an opel kadett or vauxhall viva (same car basically) they're not THAT bad.
People tend to forget how shitty European cars were in general around the 70s..

They also tend to be extremely cheap when compared to contemporary western cars due to not being that desirable.
I bought my Skoda 120GLS for 180 bucks, most of the parts were there but it was stripped almost completely and the engine was a goner, an Opel Kadett C would've been at least 800 bucks in similar condition, a KE70 Corolla would run me at least a grand in similar albeit much rustier condition because toyota.
So when you want a VERY cheap RWD winter drifter, ice ring racer or a project car, you can get old soviet cars for a fraction of the price of a western car.

>>26215669
What's cool about it is that it visits a past which was never allowed to be. Soviet cars in period weren't modified heavily, there just wasn't a car culture like there was in the USA. So cars were just left to be tools instead of a signifier.
And modifying combloc cars goes back on that, and asks questions like "what if I slammed a Niva on bags and repainted it?" or "Why not drop a v12 into a GAZ and chrome plate the grill and other trim?"
And so on.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26217599
Not only that but most of the times modifying cars in the union was varying degrees of illegal, they had quite strict inspections, you had to write down and catalogue all the modifications you did and you could only use permitted parts.
My old man had a Moskvich 408 with the opel derived 1.3 litre pushrod engine, the timing gear was glued onto a bakelite wheel that tended to crack and slip, smashing the valves into the pistons.
Old man replaced the valves twice, spun a bearing scoring the crank while doing 130kmh downhill, got a second engine from a junkyard and filed down the serial numbers and punched in his previous serial, cracked the crank on that engine and got fed up with the bullshit, replacing the whole drivetrain with an imported BMW M10B18 and a 4 speed manual from a BMW 1802 wreck that was smuggled from west germany and sold on the black market.
Helped him a lot as he was an air force pilot to pass police checkups and such

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
So as someone who's traveled in the south, east, north east, and Midwest, this is my take.

>God tier
Buc-ee's. Hands down best gas station over all. Cheap gas, clean bathrooms, good food and snack selection. Will hold it for an extra 40 miles to stop there.

>Good +1
Wawa's. Gas was average price, maybe slightly lower than surrounding big chain ones. Their food takes forever and is subway level. Bathrooms were meh. Coffee was very good. I'll pick it over others if it's not too far out of my way.

>Good
Sheetz, Loves, Pilots, and any major truck stop/rest stop. Bathrooms are acceptable, gas is fairly priced, good selection of snacks, usually has a fast food attached to it. The only places I stop on road trips if possible.

>Alright
Any big chain store gas station such as Walmart, HEB, Sam's. Gas is usually better priced, but you aren't doing anything else. Pump and go.

>Meh
Name brand gas stations such as shell, Raceway, or anything else that easily recognized. Pump and go, maybe grab a snack, restroom is for emergency only. Gas is usually more expensive, but I'll take what I can get at times

>Shit tier
Pajeet name brand owned. I only get gas there if I'm running low and it's my only option. Even then I just get enough to get me to a better place.

>Avoid at all cost
No name shit stores. They always have some nig chilling outside asking for money or shit, gas is always watered down. Keep the doors locked and drive on.

>BONUS
The toll highway stop running through Ohio and Pennsylvania. Fucking amazing highway quality, actually good views (when in PA), and there is a rest stop every 30 miles with good gas prices, clean rest rooms, snacks, and a food court with good fast food options. Only shitty thing are the tolls, but damn it was a pleasurable drive.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26213033
Competition. Up until the 1990s, the luxury car market was dominated by the Germans and the occasional bong brand. It's not that their was complacency amongst the dominant luxury brands, competition between them existed but their wasn't much incentive to innovate either.
BMW and Mercedes mostly kept to themselves. Audi and Porsche were their entirely own niche and British cars really only appealed to a more affluent and masochistic clientele. American luxury cars were the Teslas of their age; tons of technology and gimmicks with no real quality control; see Cadillacs with the Northstar as an example.
The arrival of Lexus really did change everything. It wasn't the first Japanese brand to take on the establishment but it was the first to supersede it. The Acura Legend was not impactful to the Germans; the LS400 was.
The LS in its debut was the best flagship sedan one could buy... for about two years. The LS set the gold standard for what a modern luxury sedan should be. Mercedes perfected it.
The W140's over engineered philosophy was a response to both the E32 and the LS. It was the W140 which would define the era of luxury, not Lexus. With the W140 dethroning the E32, BMW ushered an arguably even more insane car, the E38. The E38 was ahead of its time in almost every measure. It was the car of the 2000s produced in the early 1990s.
American brands did not sit idle. Lincoln perfected the luxury formula with the first Panther based Town Car in 1997. Cadillac... attempted. At least they kept the styling. Jaguar, under the influence of Ford pushed for experimentation and revived the S Type nameplate while introducing the X Type. So and so forth.
Suffice to say, the constant competition and wider variety of luxury offerings created a market which was not oversaturated, rather a market where every option was respectable and understandable. Every car had a merit for existing and manufacturers had to constantly compete and innovate to justify that merit.

posts.com:
>>26219054
EZPZ but with some steps:

Get a tap and drill and long bolt that's about half the diameter of the shaft

Get a drill guide, OD is slightly less than the ID of the diff
ID is slightly more than the drill bit
insert drill guide into diff
this is to prevent the drill bit from wandering and to keep it on center
slowly drill a hole in the broken CV shaft
once you drill it deep enough, use the tap to thread it
then you take your bolt, thread it in and use the bolt to yank out the chunk of cv shaft

repeat for the other side

Failing that, ask a local mechanic shop who they use to burn out broken taps and take your trans there and have them remove the chunks, it shouldn't cost more than a hundred bucks.

You can also look it up online, look for EDM shops (Electronic Discharge Machining). That's what you use to burn broken taps out of engine blocks. I say the word burn but the edm process actually creates very little heat.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26219054
Get round tubing big enough for the stinger of the welder, a slide hammer, a vise grip, and a couple 3/8 bolts.
Weld the tubing to the axle shaft, weld the bolt to the tubing, and attach the vise grip to the slide hammer for removal. A 5lb slide hammer kit normally has a weird threaded attachment. it's for threading in the adjuster spot on a large pair of vise grips.
You don't want to have to split the case. Best chance to get the weld to stick is preheating, try to not fuck your axle seals.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26217932
Owned this one, it was my first bike.
They are called the GPX600R (and pre 1988 GPZ600R).

The bike is pretty easy to work on, the only problem point can be getting the carbs on/off as the airbox is jammed in the frame. If you replace the airbox for pods, you will have a much easier time working on it. For the rest its just a standard 4IL jap engine. It shares many parts with other kawa bikes of the time period. Get the Haynes manual if you plan to do your own work and you will be good.
The bike is super comfy, and has plenty of power for beginners/intermediate riders, although it can be quite peaky.
Also the tires of this bike are interesting, as they are 16" instead of the more common 17". Personally I have found the Bridgestone Battlax BT45 excellent on the bike.

Those Shadows (not to be confused with older V4 Sabres) are reliable bikes. If it runs well there's no "tuning" to do. In future always post the year and end the habit of saying "this bike" when identifying a machine. It will not kill you to be specific. There is zero reason for anons to not be and it's a very very recent zoomer meme best ended especially for tech questions. It has hydraulic lifters so don't neglect oil and filter changes. Remove spark plugs and inspect per color charts online. I always perform a cold compression test when I get a new-to-me used bike for reference.

Water pump swaps are a good place to save money as the labor cost easily pays for any tools required, and unlike the labor you own the tools. Inspect hoses and replace any which are an asspain to do while you're in there anyway.

shadow sabre water pump change site:www.hondashadow.net

If you replace the fan control thermal switch I would still parallel that with a toggle so if it fails again you just flip the switch and ride. There is something of an art to riding old bikes for many years which I do.

Not all leaks or seepages matter enough to fix. You may find a manual for download here and of course tips on water pump replacement.

https://www.hondashadow.net/forums/technical-discussion.72/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26218756
A small dot in the middle of the threads or the first three towards the plug shell of quality high temp anti-seize is a good idea to prevent sticking. About the size of this O is fine then rub into the threads. Just keep it away from the tip and do not overtorque plugs. It's used often in aviation where stripping threads is REALLY expensive. (I'm also an AMT and retired jet engine troop etc)

Most noobs trowel it on with predictable results so automotive plug mfrs notably NGK play it safe and say to rely on their plating. Their old bulletin said to use anti-seize on NON-plated NGK plugs.

IME properly applied anti-seize is effective and I have never over hundreds of plugs I've installed and removed since the late 1970s overtorqued one or had one short or loosen due to anti-seize.

OTOH every customer plug (I part-timed at my mentors multibrand shop for many years) that was stuck and sheared off despite the usual penetrant soak was installed dry. Every plug that peeled out an installed heli-coil on customer bikes was installed dry (fuck coil inserts in alloy heads, I use pinned Time-Serts). Car and truck plugs (fucking Fords...) also benefit.

Dielectric grease is for plug boots, electrical connectors (excludes moisture preventing corrosion) and makes tidy anti-seize for small visible hardware like control switch screws and clamp screws.

Spark plug-specific anti-seize exists but I use either nickel high temp or quality copper (Jet Lube) as well:

https://skygeek.com/spplthlu4ozb.html

Champion instructions note it CAN be eliminated with inserts but I never omit it.

https://www.championaerospace.com/assets/technical/90-4.pdf

There are many places on a bike where torque wrenches don't fit. Picrel is from NGK tech data showing the angle method:

What's fascinating for me is the sheer variety of machines during this era of sports car racing. Especially in the early days of BPR and Le Mans before the manufacturers flooded in.
In GT1 you had oddities like
>Aston Martin DB7 LM GT1
>Bugatti EB110SC
>Callaway C7R
>Chevy Corvette C4 ZR-1
>De Tomaso Pantera GT1
>Jaguar XJ220C
>Lotus Esprit GT1
>Nissan 300ZX IMSA
>Renault Spider GT1
>Porsche 911 GT2 Evo

And over in GT2, you have even weirder shit
>Callaway Supernatural Corvette LM
>Ferrari 348 and 355s
>Marcos LM600
>Morgan Plus 8 GTR
>Saleen Mustang GT2
>VBM 4000 GTC
>Venturi 400/500/600LM

Half of them weren't anywhere near competitive against the F40s and later the Mclaren F1s but it's interesting to see what smaller teams would throw together in a shitbox to try and make them work.
It's sad that something like this will probably never be replicated again.

Whoever this is is moron talking out of his ass and doesn't understand that technical regulations don't stay static for decades. Rules change and cars can be eligible for different categories. The McLaren F1 didn't race under the same GT1 regs in 1997 as it did in the years prior. The Toyota GT-One was recategorized as a GTP when GT1 was cancelled. The Viper GTS/R raced as a GT1 in its first year, then rehomologated as a GT2. It'd also race under the IMSA/ACO rules in the GTS category. Then you had the Maserti MC-12 which didn't conform to re-vamped GT1 regs of mid-'00s, but was granted homologation on a waiver anyway because Mosley demanded it.

The main takeaway is that rules change and different racing series can categorize cars as they see fit. GT1 in 1994 was not the same as GT1 in 2005 or GTS in 2001 or GT in 2003. They are all different rule sets.

>>26194907
The desolation in sportscar racing caused by the subsequent collapse of Gr.C (and Gr.B a few years before) led to fans looking at more national-level and single-make series to get their fix. Under these circumstances, Venturi made their own one-make series in 1992 called the Gentleman Driver's Trophy for amateurs which garnered a lot of attention despite being side-events for bigger races. The series used their 400 Trophy racecar and got a lot of response from teams. In charge of the series was Venturi's head of competition services, Stephane Ratel, who is practically the godfather of the modern GT era. In 1993, facing a dwindling prototype field, the ACO allowed production-based cars to fill the rest of the grid for the first time since 1986. The response to their Trophy series and a chance for competing at the LM24, Venturi stepped up to the plate with the 500LM and were represented by no less than 7 cars. They didn't win, but most of the cars actually succeeded in finishing the race.

In 1994, Ratel teamed up with Jurgen Barth and Patrick Peter to make the BPR series which would aim to become the first intercontinental sportscar series since Gr.C folded. Ratel would apply his connections from the Trophy series to get teams to race in BPR giving Venturi a strong presence in a field that would otherwise be a slew of 911s and a single F40 for most of the races. The BPR would continue to grow in 1995 and 1996 with Venturi competing every year until it was taken over by the FIA. During the BPR years Ratel would form the SRO which has been shaping GT racing for almost 30 years.

>>26195544
First, nice Double-Dubs.

Second, something to add was that the performance spike and extremely high running costs of Group C & GTP cars in America in the early 1990s lead to many privateer teams and gentlemen drivers to look elsewhere, which in turn lead to a rise in One-Make series like the Porsche Super Cup and the Ferrari Challenge series. The head if Porsche's competition department at the time? Jurgen Barth.

The biggest mover and shaker in the Ferrari Challenge series when it launched in the 1990s? Patrick Peter.

By early 1993, Stephane Ratel, Barth and Peter started organizing special race weekends where teams in their one-make series that were up for it raced against each other. By Le Mans that year, the BPR GT series was starting to take shape and they just so happened to use the rulebook Le Mans came up with for 1994.

I think Peter's clout back in the '90s was promoting events, especially vintage motorsport. Before BPR, his organization brought back the modern interpretation of the French Tour Auto event in 1992. He would later go on to start the Le Mans Classic in the early-'00s. His connection was useful in filling up the grid as many teams were just amateur drivers that owned or maintained classic racecars.

Barth was basically just famous for his career as a Porsche factory driver having 4 class wins at LM24 with one of those being an outright win in a 936. He was just there to put a famous face on the series and his final class win happened just months before the first BPR race. Essentially the spokesman, he held a lot of celebrity sway over Porsche enthusiasts (and probably why so many teams on the grid were driving Porsches)

Ratel was the main guy running the whole operation. He also used his connections at Venturi to get teams from the Trophy series to sign on to BPR and step up the Trophy cars to one of the new 500LM racecars.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Jesus Christ, too many normies in this thread flinging shit at each other without actually knowing whose shit it is.

The GTS/R originally raced as a GT1 car when it debuted in 1996. Back then the main deciding factor of which category a car belonged was based on engine displacement. The Viper being 8.0L was firmly designated for GT1. When the FIA revised their rules for 1997 (mainly to allow for more exotic cars and technology like the CLK GTR), Chrysler had the GTS/R rehomologated for FIA's GT2. For the US races, they would race under the SCCA's GT2 category for USRRC races and IMSA/ACO's GTS category for ALMS. When USRRC gave way to Grand-Am, the GTS/R was in the GTO category until they renamed it GTS (many of the same cars as ACO, but under GARRA's rules) until Vipers were no longer running in the series. These different categories in different series were basically analogous to FIA's pre-'97 regs.

When ACO adopted the FIA's newly revised GT regs essentially adapting the old GTS and GT classes as new GT1 and GT2, the GTS/R was categorized as a GT1 under the new rules. By adopting the ACO's GTS rules, in a round-about way, the FIA returned to GT1 back to what it was before the 1997 changes.

That's the 1999 D24. That event was part of the USRRC in those days which ran under the SCCA rules. Under those rules, the C5-R (and the EMR Corvette) was categorized as a GT2 which was a ported version of FIA GT1 for the US. So the "GT2" decal on the car does denote the category car is racing in because it's an SCCA GT2 which is different from FIA GT2.

>>26190497
The story of the 911 GT1 is a silly one. The only reason why Porsche got into GT1 in the first place was because their 1995 prototype project fell through and ACO banned them from racing a 962 in a GT category after '94. Instead of complying with the rules of not entering a prototype in a GT class, they would build a new prototype and have the rules changed later and so they came out with the 911 GT1 for '96. They'd win some races in BPR, but because it wasn't homologated at the time, it didn't count for any championship points. When the FIA took over BPR and updated the rules, irony Porsche as it was getting beaten at their own game by the new Mercedes and updated McLaren. For most of the program, the car was getting its butt-kicked in FIA GT and could only muster a few non-championship exhibition races. Their only consolation prize was a championship in the national-level BGTC.

It was in 1998 that they went go-for-broke in the final year of the program and completely revised the car. They still got their ass handed to them in FIA GT (and lost their BGTC crown to a McLaren team), but they did end up winning Le Mans. However to do it, Porsche had to buyout the LMP team that had been beating them over the last two years and "upgrade" their cars. Both would DNF leaving the GT1 cars the sole factory-supported team. The biggest irony was that the LMP car that kept beating them before was the using Porsche's abandoned prototype project from before.

The final black eye of the program was at the final race of the factory program at the very first Petite Le Mans where they DNF'd by managing to get the car airborne and flip over end-over-end.

A stupid end to a stupid car.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26188658
It's probably nothing, Accords have a high pitched noise at high rpm anyway.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26188770

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26189184
>this car rarely revs up, it's always at around 2k or less RPMs
That's because you're driving a based Accord, doesn't need to rev a lot to do work, but they do sound very unhappy at high rpms, the whole cylinder head is setup to run below 2400 rpm with half the intake valves shut off while cruising in 5th gear.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26189191

I didn't know. So it's best to be conservative when going uphill?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26189193
If you need to downshift the transmission to pass someone or to go up a hill, feel free to press that pedal down as far as you have to, your car can handle it, the car just likes low rpms and high gears to save fuel, but even revving to over 6000 rpm won't hurt it.

>>26202738
I've owned 2 ashtray cars.
the car will always have a smell of stale tobacco, mainly during hot days but, you can get most of it out.
I copied the typical "disaster detail" steps you see in yt vids complete with seat removal, center console removal, deep vacuuming, soap, borax, and oxiclean solutions used with an extractor and drill brush on every soft surface.
the only spot I didn't hit super hard was the headliner because it was already weak in some areas.
even after all that it leeches out some stink in the summer heat. charcoal or baking soda cabin filter helps a lot if you run recirculation

it might be worth it if it isn't that bad and you can tolerate the smell.

>>26206576
That's the entire issue of shitty public transport infrastructure.
Look at a country like the Netherlands. Everything there is designed to have an alternative to the car.
For cities you've got bicycles, dedicated bike lanes and routes which are often faster than taking a car.
For regional transport you've got buses and a plethora of bus lanes, if you want to go somewhere there's a 90% chance a bus will take you there.
For longer trips you've got trains. Often faster than rush hour traffic, though I will concede the train service isn't the best here.

I also hate public transport and you'd never catch me in either a bus or train, but the ability to use an alternative to the car (With the exception of living in a small town in the northern part of the country) is there, something which a lot of normies use, and something which makes our roads far less congested than American roads despite our insane population density.

Public transport is good because it keeps others off the road so that you can enjoy it in peace.

The increasing cost of personal transportation will push the poorest out of car ownership. Which will increase the tax burden on the middle class paying for their cars. And that will push more out of car ownership.
More cars off the road means less traffic jams.
Buses are already more economical, environmentally friendly, and more efficient than cars when you have three riders. You can afford to run empty buses all day because of that.

From there we just wake people up to the fact that the majority of the east coast was built on streetcar suburbs. Plow the postwar suburb down and rebuild that for density. Car suburbs are fucking cancer and no one likes them anyway. Everyone's moving to the city or the country, no in between. Get rid of it.
Also we could re-zone much of the car suburbs to return them to the farms they were originally built from. I know in my town, pretty well the whole '50-'95 expansion was built on farms.

So after we get density solved and the poorest out of driving (and let's be honest, if you can't keep maintaining a car, you shouldn't have one, live within your means) then traffic will start to go down. Eliminating the hypercommute of 2+h will go a long way to eliminating traffic as a problem. Most young people don't want to live far from work anymore, since it doesn't usually save money.
After that, we could build rural streetcars and build up bus routes in the country. Again the east coast of the USA had these interurban electric railways, so it's literally just going to take reclaiming the land and building it back. It should have never left, since that handled the commute for farm workers prior to the '60s when they were ripped out to make way for temporary foreign workers, corn syrup farms, and bloated car infrastructure.
And of course there's going to be people who don't want to take public transportation, but I don't care. This can absolutely be scaled out for the flyover and remote communities.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26216726
There are two electric motor/generator units (MGU).
One is mounted on the turbo shaft to spin the turbo at low revs and to generate electricity when the turbo is spinning fast (full throttle). The turbo at full throttle produces more boost than the engine needs so the excess energy is instead used to spin the generator (MGU-H - H for heat).
The other MGU is placed on the drive shaft of the engine, before the clutch (like a regular starter motor). It can be used as either an electric motor to increase total power or as a generator to brake the rear wheels alongside the regular brakes to charge the battery.
In this way, the car can charge the battery both during full throttle acceleration (straights) and under braking.
The total energy released by the battery is capped per lap, so not all energy available through this regen can actually be deployed.
The 2026 engine rules change intends to increase this cap, among other things.

>reliability overblown
Anything can be overblown on the internet, but these do stand head and shoulders above their contemporaries. It's the build quality that is the real virtue though.
Shut the door of one, listen and feel it, and get back to me. For that matter, use the hazard lights switch of an early one as well. Oh, and check out the wear profile of MB-tex w123 seats at 300k miles. Oh and try to find a w123 whose factory rustproofing under the floorpans wore through (they will only rust from water pooling above; inside the car). It is true that these cars will die eventually if totally neglected, but there are stories of them running with a knock so bad it eats an entire piston until there is just a gnarled conrod left, and still going. It is true that some modern cars can pretty easily make 300k, maybe even some current German cars, but nothing at the price point of an E-class is built overall to the level of craftsmanship today that these were back then. And when parts do fail, the parts themselves are usually able to be disassembled and repaired e.g. replacing o-rings in the self leveling suspension valve, or replacing a simple check valve in the vacuum pump. Granted, they were also ~$32k in the early 1980s but much of that is due to crazy exchange rates with the deutschmark.

Picrel: the turbo compressor wheel of my previously neglected car at 330k miles when I got it; no intercooler to catch that debris that obviously left, but all cylinders still had compression within 5% of factory acceptable tolerance. Ran totally fine just didnt make any boost.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
For completeness I will post common w123 issues:
-Valve lash adjustment every 11k miles
-Fuel filters need changing, including the filter screen in the 40 year old rusty gas tank that is a bit of a mess and pain to access.
-Vacuum pump needs to work to turn off the car with the key, may need rebuild (replacements are NLA)
-turbos don't last, and are NLA. Good luck finding one NOS for under $1,000
-Injection pumps wear out with low sulfur fuel and are more mechanically complex than the rest of the engine. Can be rebuilt for now, parts supply is running low.
-wagon hydraulic rear self levelling suspension is robust, but nobody ever changes the fluid so it may be a corroded mess, hydraulic shocks are close to $1000
-injectors last 200k miles, with a poor spray pattern they can wear out the prechambers (NLA) and wash the oil film off the cylinders by spraying direct into the bores. This and low oil are the two surefire ways to kill an OM617. Injector rebuild costs ~$500 or more, done by some guy you find on a forum.
-alternator mounted voltage regulator fails. However, the alternator is beefy as fuck and has two belts for redundancy which is awesome. Retards bend/mutilate the alt adjustment bolt, which can make changing the alternator a royal pain.
-leaks. Holy shit you will stain every driveway or road you park on. Learn to park on gravel dirt or grass. The rms is a rope seal, requires engine or transmission removal. They also leak from the connection between the oil filter housing and block; gasket was the wrong material from factory.
-diesel in general is absolutely filthy. Fortunately the oil leaks on mine coated the original exhaust so it didnt rust after 40 years in NY/NJ.
Basically, even though these were incredibly popular and common cars, parts dry up for old cars until demand is high enough for someone to churn out one run of a specific part in an african sweatshop. So you need to be a little bit of a hoarder of spare parts to have one as a daily.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26206125
I have a 300D turbo (I love it: forever car) and will have to disagree with you on a few points.

The turbos do last, mine did 300k before I replaced it and it's just getting into the region of "might want to rebuild it". These are dumb simple garrett T3s, a rebuild kit is $30 and an hour of your time, and you're good for another 300k. You can also put in an aftermarket turbo easily with kits sold by benzforce (I did it, he221w gang).

the injection pumps will wear out eventually on ULSD, so put a little oil of any kind (2 stroke is good) in at every fillup.

Yes, wagon SLS will go. They can be rebuilt cheaply, or SLS deleted with a kit for a few hundred.

vacuum pumps are a very rare failure, it is always the vacuum system leaking somewhere. just fix the leak of block it off.

injector rebuilds are NOT $500, what are you smoking. The forum guy does it for $100 for a set and you can do it yourself for $30/nozzle and a $80 pop tester if you're like that.

ADDITIONAL issues:
climate control nonsense, usually the actuators developing leaks.
the tach will stop working due to bad connection in the tach amp.
the steering box will get loose over time and need tightening

Many. 1990s-2000s was when drivetrain longevity was more or less perfected without constant maintenance. >P2096 Code: Post Catalyst Fuel Trim System Too Lean (Bank 1)
could be a vacuum leak. get a propane torch, turn it on without lighting it, and run it up and down all your vacuum lines, hoses, intake, etc with the engine running. if you hit a spot where the engine speeds up, you've found your leak.
i would also clean your MAF sensor (with maf cleaner spray) as a faulty maf can cause unexpected readings at your o2 sensor.
could also be one or more clogged fuel injector, remove them and soak in carb cleaner, you can even apply 12V to the injector to open it as you spray a can of carb cleaner through to test the spray pattern and clean the insides

>When accelerating between 2k-3k rpm, there's a very intense deep humming/vibration from the front
could be a failing CV joint

>>26205607
absolutely, there is nothing wrong with doing that. that's actually one of the things that people who live in very cold climates do to keep their batteries from dying overnight when it's 40 below.
the agm setting likely makes it float charge (~13.5v) once the battery is nearly full rather than having it at full 14.4v the whole time because non flooded batteries require it to not get cooked. I don't think there's any detriment or benefit to using it, there's just no point. just set it to normal and charge and it'll be good to go.

That black smoke is from incomplete combustion, because it's running absolutely pig rich. posts.com: My battery is corroded. Been fine but then it was cold the other day and i had to get jumped. Drove 20 yards and it died. Happened again today. Jump, drive a few feet and it dies. Could it be bad terminals/battery? Or is it definitely the alternator? Thanks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26206819
Could be either, clean the terminals with water and a wire brush and make sure they're tight. If you have a voltmeter, check the voltage at the terminals while it's running, you should see 13-14 volts. If it's 12.6 or under your alternator is either not working or its connection to the battery is bad. If it's not too difficult to get to, check the voltage at it's output stud too to make sure it's not the wire that's bad.

Anyone who tries to convince you not to buy an in shape car of any make/model with 100k miles is a literal disingenuous car salesman jew.

no, i dont think this is related to a vacuum leak. something is fucked with your electrical system. check your belt that it's in place, check all your wiring harnesses for mouse chew marks, torn or broken bits that could be shorted against metal, stuff like that.
what is your battery voltage with the car off and with the car running?
if it's not a chewed up wire, it's possible your alternator is going and it's alternating between putting out too much and too little current, or there is a reference wire that hooks into the alternator that it reads the vehicle voltage from, if that wire is loose or corroded or something it can cause the alt to produce too much or too little voltage.

if it's a fair price for the car and in your budget then yeah no need to negotiate it, but they will try to tack on extra fees that you can say no to

Keep in mind that particular dealership has these as well
>$250 documentation, and any other fees required by law. The advertised price of used vehicles does not include a $495 reconditioning/prep fee.
often just called "$250 dealership processing fee" and "$495 reconditioning fee". They will never negotiate on the processing fee. The reconditioning fee they might

The reconditioning fee they'll say is the 'average' amount they have to spend on all their used cars to get them ready for sale, like new tires, wiper blades, etc. If the wearable items look well used then you can just tell them the detail job looks like one you could do in 30 minutes in your own garage and these other items were definitely not replaced.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Question is probably stupid, sorry.
Intake/exhaust valves are circular because they rotate, right? That way it doesn't matter how much they rotate, they will always sit right.
Question: wouldn't it be good to make valves of non-circular shapes in order to fill more of the cylinder head area, and if so, wouldn't it be possible to make valves that don't rotate? Like have them on some kind of rail system or whatever so they can't rotate.
I know nothing about mechanics or engineering sorry if I asked something really stupid.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26217793
>Intake/exhaust valves are circular because they rotate, right?

Valves don't typically rotate, they can slightly during use but its not necessary to their function.

>wouldn't it be good to make valves of non-circular shapes in order to fill more of the cylinder head area,

Not really. Non-ovoid or non-circular shapes are much much more difficult to engineer to seal correctly, and in the case of most engines heat also plays a role, as circular shapes also tend to heat up uniformly at a much more predictable rate. If you were say to use a rectangle or polygonal style of shape, the corners would heat up more quickly than the rest of the mass of the valve which beyond causing more wear, would also cause seat and sealing issues.

>>26218971
>2008 Grand Cherokee with the 5.7 Hemi.
Lifter failures aren't that common in the 2005-2009 Hemis. What kills those is either a broken valve spring resulting in a dropped valve, or a valve seat falling out due to heat and insufficient press fit from the factory. Interestingly a dropped seat can result in a lifter tap for a short while before it breaks and fucks the engine completely.

>>26217240
>Consider build quality, price AND performance.
I've owned Japanese, american, and European cars of various categories so I'll offer my take.
American cars, as for most of our history, ar3 about delivering the best thrills for the least money. The sacrifice has always come in the form of build quality, fit and finish, and depending on the car, reliability. 80s C4s, mustangs, camaros, so on, all have horrible interiors. They feel cheap, poorly made. Often they suffer from factory defects, optispark, tfi modules, weak frames, etc. On the flip side you get access to a very capable platform and huge aftermarket, with cheap manual v8s abound. American cars are also (usually) easy to maintain if we pretend the fbody doesn't exist.
I don't think any one continent does it better. They all have pros and cons, it just depends on what you value.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Chrysler brands focus on powerful drivetrains, Ford has clever engineering and GM tends to be the less ambitious but more reliable car manufacturer.

Mopars in general are a bit of a rolling joke. Because Chrysler focuses on impressive power figures, tow capacity or handling competency, their cars are built the cheapest, they have the worst quality control, yet are engineered around this concept: they build cars that are easy to (dis)assemble with the idea the end user is probably going to try fixing the machine himself rather than visiting a mechanic. They sell factory upgrades and have great parts support, even for old models. They are really slow to develop new technology often using the same powertrains for decades, sometimes developing them while in production, and only updating the interior package in the car as needed to keep up with consumer tastes.

Ford is the opposite, they engineer competent powertrains right out of the gate (with exceptions) and have the best handle on interior comfort and durabilitiy of the three, and their cars aesthetically tend toward futuristic. Their problem is they cannot leave well-enough alone over time, and maintaining one of their cars can be a nightmare depending which model year you have with lots of incremental changes of the course of a platforms life. They also love using plastic where it probably doesn't need to be.

GM is fantastic at making one thing: pushrod V8s. They try hard to match Ford's styling game but have sub-Chrysler levels of build quality. Unlike Chrysler where the cars are engineered well and just made badly, GM cars are made pretty well but from carelessly developed parts. Degrading plastics, weird GM smell from that develops after a while, unsealed PCBs for engine electronics, special coolant that rots the cars it's meant to go in, and let's not even bring up their drunken stepfather tendency of sabotaging anything that does better than Chevy or the Corvette.

>>26215330
What happened is they had to make the oil pan shorter so it would fit and/or the car would have a lower center of gravity, and so it had less oil than a normal iron duke. Also, GM fucked up the connecting rods (between 10 and 40% of them I think) so they weren't as strong as they should've been.

What could happen is you'd be out ripping in your Fiero, maybe a little low on oil, and then, as a result of oil starvation, one of your conrods would break, window the block, and splooge oil onto your exhaust and then it would catch fire.

That was only for the 84 4 cylinder ones though. I've heard of V6 ones catching on fire because of leaves and stuff collecting on the engine or other hot things, but I suppose that could happen to any car.

AW11 has great 80s wedge styling with popups, 100-140hp engines, and overall great handling with minimal snap oversteer.
SW20 got fatter and started really suffering from snap oversteer due to weight and higher power. The styling is quintessentially 90s Japan.
W30 Spyders are kinda like Japanese Porsches. Haven't really heard anything bad about them, but they also still go for a fair bit of money. Not a huge fan of the styling but to each their own.
AFAIK unlike the Fiero there is no outstanding problems with catching fire. I'm unsure if the mods you can make to any MR2 are easier to reach a performance goal versus the Fiero, however.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26215330
>muh Fiero caught fire

I dunno about the catching fire but back in 1986 I was cruising around with my buddy drinking beer in my mom's 1978 Oldsmobile Cutlas Supreme Broham (with a slow as fuck 260ci two-barrel) and we were rolling up on a red light that had just turned green.

There was a Fiero waiting in front of us and it started going thru the intersection and right at that point, my buddy and I looked over at the crossing road and saw a Chevy Chevette just flying up the road and we both said "hey, that guy ain't stopping!"

The Chevette went right thru the red light and hammered the Fiero on the driver's side front wheel and pretty much ripped the entire front end off, sending the Fiero spinning like top and bouncing three times while red plastic rained down on my car as we slowly rolled thru the intersection.

I pulled into a party store parking lot (what we call convenience stores here in MI) and my buddy and I ran out to the Fiero expecting the driver to be gruesomely dead but he had his seatbelt on and was just stunned a bit (he had broken out the driver's side window with his head) and got out of the Fiero to look at it, when the Chevette driver came over and apologized (he was unhurt).

I was interviewed by cops (but not my buddy, he was still 17 at the time) and despite them obviously smelling the beer on my breath, they didn't give me any shit and a few weeks later, the Fiero driver's lawyer called and said the Chevette driver had been drunk and would I be willing to testify in court, to which I said yes, though I was never called.

So my experience is that Fieros are pretty sturdy.
