posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26214796
Love the look of them, bought an 88 gt over a year ago that needed some minor work and had a fun time scooting around town for awhile.
Unfortunately sold it due to a few reasons.
Headroom is great, but If you're over 6ft, leg room is an issue and gets more annoying the longer you have it and hit the same spots over and over again on your knees.
Coupled with this, the pedals are all pretty far inboard and compound this issue further.
Interior is gm parts-bin so make of that what you will, not a huge issue but you can definitely feel how cheap it is.
Replacing window motors are a massive pain in the ass, they're hard to get to unless you take the inner AND outer door skins off and on top of that they're under a shitload of spring load so you have to be careful not to crush or slice your fingers off when you remove them.
Fiero store parts are hit or miss, and are usually your only option unless you can find a parts car or someone parting out one on ebay.
For example I replaced the sunroof weatherstripping and was lucky that the metal guides underneath weren't rusted to shit as replacements have been reported to turn to dust in a year or two.
Despite being a small car the lack of power steering and somewhat underpowered v6 is noticeable and a bit of a bummer.
I was debating on doing a ls4 or 3800 swap but eventually decided against it, when you substantially increase power on these things you need to beef up the shock mounts and a few other things or it will tear itself apart.
It was more work than I wanted to put into a $6k car.
People love them though, almost everyone who talked to me about it either had one in the past or knew someone who did.
That can be a plus or negative depending on how social you are.
Honestly wasn't a bad experience overall, looked cool, good on gas, drove nicely with the 88 suspension, and much of it was easy enough to work on, but inevitably breaking 40 year old plastic every time I fixed something got old fast.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
DIY Ebike Owner here.

Batteries on their own won't combust if they are not currently powering something. The security systems of EV's draw the power from the 12v circuit.
The other problem is wire and circuit management. A bunch of wires together can still radiate power between each other like electromagnetic fields, and higher voltage systems can destabilize fixed electro radiation frequencies of lower voltage direct current systems. The problem is the EV car have two direct current circuits with near the same amp loads for their voltages. Overloading amps is the same as sparking wires, and those sparking wires are melted solder after they are done. If there is no safety fuse or controller to cut off that, then the amp overload will cycle though the battery and then boom. The problem about that safety shutoff is your car and it's by wire system will no longer operable.
The problem is EV's have two voltage systems on the platform, so the cause is most likely electromagnetic radiation form the higher voltage getting into the lower voltage wires. The wires from both circuits are most likely not the same gauge to handle the same Watts. There is no need for a low voltage wire near a high voltage motor, or battery.

Short answer is the electrical circuits in EV's are shit and that's the only reason they spontaneously combust. The risk is only higher in high watt systems like the Tesla and Lucid because of the greater voltage difference between the power and accessory circuits.

posts.sub: Does anyone do mechanic work part time?
posts.com:
I like working on my car and am considering becoming a part time oil monkey at a dealership near me. I have no experience other than working on my own car, and am a software engineer full time.

Is this a dumb idea, and would I end up hating the work?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26217504
Depends on how you would get paid. If hourly, you'll be fine. Essentially getting paid just to be there. If flate rate, fuck that. Rather than getting paid for how long you're on the clock, you'd be getting paid for how much work you do. Considering you'd be an entry level lubie who's gonna be getting a lot of warranty oil changes and super basic services, you won't be able to rack up enough hours to make it worth your while. Full-time flat rate guys make their money in diagnosis and big jobs, and you won't be touching any of that. Also, try to apply for a brand that gets more affluent customers like Audi, Mercedes, Volvo, etc. The poorer the customer base, the less likely they'll approve work for brakes, tires, etc. Lastly if you're not big and strong, try avoiding working at a brand that sells a lot of pickup trucks. Tire rotations on heavy duty trucks will wear you out if that's what you're doing all day long

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26215355
You're describing a wide variety of issues that could be anywhere from nothing to extreme engine issues. Coil packs is a very odd place to start.

Just spitballing from other issues I've ran into:
>Check your coolant level and condition
A milkshake in the coolant is immediately obvious of a head gasket issue. Alternatively, if the level is oddly low, it's getting used somewhere, likely a coolant leak or head gasket leak. Check coolant reservoir for bubbles while running; if it's bubbling, it's leaking combustion gases into the coolant system (head gasket).
>Milky under the oil fill cap, but not the dipstick
This is super common for people who drive short distances or in cold weather, amplified if both. As some other anon said, this is condensation mixing with the oil. Under normal circumstances, the oil is hot enough to boil off this condensation. However, under short drives or extremely cold conditions, the oil doesn't heat up enough to get rid of the excessive moisture. Go on a long drive to resolve.
>Smoke under the hood
What? Under no circumstance is that normal. Source and rectify immediately. See if smoke is coming from coolant reservoir (head gasket leak).
>Sputter on ignition
Wide variety of things could cause this. Spark plug condition will give you the most information on this. Plugs would be very ashy and white if it's coolant. They will be black and sooty if it's too rich (from faulty coolant temperature sensor perhaps). They should be ash-free, with a dark brown to a light tan color on the insulator portion.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26215601
>Smoke out the exhaust
White smoke from the exhaust indicates water vapor. This could be from the engine/exhaust not being fully warmed up in cooler weather conditions, or from a leaking head gasket. Wait until engine is fully warmed up after a drive and re-evaluate. If it's sill spewing white smoke (not just a little bit from condensation / cold), then it's likely head gasket.
>Coolant temp sensor
Investigate further. Regardless of ambient temperature, it shouldn't be throwing a code for this.

That should be enough rope to hang yourself with. Good luck.

Okay, so, I don't know what to say. It's hard to diagnose without being physically seeing it, and your description is pretty vague. To be brutally honest, I don't think you have an issue at all; I think you saw something that you thought was a problem. Other than the smoke under the hood (maybe frost or a mild oil leak on the exhaust from cylinder head would be my speculation), I don't read anything that's alarming.

I would recommend the following:
>Check coolant level and condition as described previously
>Every few days, check engine oil dipstick if it's milky or not
